section.text: Oh, thanks so much. I think perhaps two questions. I mean, Tom, what a career, and Chris, congratulations. I wanted to ask about Spectrum One first. And Tom, it reminds me of when you launched the triple-play, was it 2005 back when FiOS and U-verse were launching, and it looked like a really intriguing price and value for customers, but also kind of lower than perhaps prior promotions. So I'm just hoping that you and Chris can walk through the strategy behind the Spectrum One promotion and the financial impact relative to your prior promotional strategies. And then separately, Chris, I know it's early, and you're indicating that you're going to update us in December. Like how broadly are you considering, be it all the strategy shifts, obviously investors are kind of combination of nervous and excited about changes that might take place? I mean, is there scope to rapidly accelerate capital spending or different pricing strategies? How wide is the net here in terms of what you're considering? Is this revolution or evolution? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Douglas Mitchelson", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "1ccf8537-1ff3-4d0c-a0b6-954acc39a6a1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Well, thanks, Doug. Yeah, your memory is good. And I'll turn that answer over to Chris, but when triple-play was first announced, there was a lot of skepticism. And some people thought it was foolish, but it turned out to be quite successful.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "bbb2b74b-8421-4027-b83e-f512d2c5be9d", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Yeah. So, I think there is similarly maybe a little confusion out there about what Spectrum One is. And really it's our first attempt, and it may evolve over-time. But Spectrum One packages seamless connectivity with our products, and they all work better together. It's offered at a first-year promotional price. And as a result, our pricing of the underlying products, whether that's Internet, advanced WiFi and mobile, it has not changed. Even after that promotional period, Spectrum One creates values for customers in a way that our competitors really can't replicate. It's pretty similar to what was the design of Tom's original triple-play. And we also attach additional products or mobile lines to that promotional sell-in. So contrary to what I think is maybe a fear, we have not lowered our pricing in the marketplace, nor do we believe that we need to.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "85db7159-18dc-4bc4-a61d-d733bd41618e", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Doug, on strategy shift, I mean in the prepared remarks, I wanted to be clear. But I understand that's out there as well. I've been a key player in developing our operating strategy here with Tom and John Bickham and others over the past decade. And just because somebody gives you a new title, doesn't mean that your view on fundamentally how to create shareholder value changes overnight. So I'm pretty committed to all things that we're doing today in terms of our strategy, products, pricing, packaged service. As I mentioned, our capital structure, I honestly had a little bit of a hand in that as well, in our balance sheet and M&A strategy. So I don't expect any seismic shifts. And I've always thought that if we were going to do something anyway in terms of capital, might as well go get after it, so you can grow faster. And so if there is opportunities to accelerate what we're already doing, we'll do that. But I don't think people should expect any fundamental changes and views on how we operate the business or how we create value for shareholders.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "85db7159-18dc-4bc4-a61d-d733bd41618e", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Douglas Mitchelson", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "d47505ce-f754-4950-87c7-ac49d4dda7bd", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Thanks, Doug. Katie, we'll take our next question, please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stefan Anninger", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "23e3e491-332a-41e2-94f9-303e7b5dded4", "speaker_title": "Head of Investor Relations at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thank you. And congrats, Tom. I'm sure we'll miss you more than you'll miss us, but please stay in touch. [Speech Overlap] Yeah, I guess sticking with the wireless theme and the network, Chris, last quarter, you were willing to highlight to us that maybe we on the sell-side had got the wireless economics wrong. Obviously, you've gotten -- you've got the Spectrum One plan in the market, which seems to be doing what you hoped it would, which is drive faster growth. I'm sure we'll see more of that in Q4. The losses in wireless, and I know product P&Ls are of limited use to some extent. But they look like they'll be pretty flattish year-on-year this year. I'm just wondering is there anyway you can sort of take us into the cost structure on the wireless side, speak to the network offload opportunities? And is there any way to help us think about -- as you continue down this convergence path, is there a timeline towards EBITDA starting to inflect and really benefit from the wireless revenue scale you're building? Because it sounds like -- looks like we're not going to see that at least in the near-term. And then I'm just wondering what are the returns you're seeing on the high-split activity so far? And you mentioned DOCSIS 4.0, Tom did in his prepared remarks. Do you have a sort of a timeline you want to sort of lay out for us or how you think about the benefits of high-split and DOCSIS 4.0 over the course of next few years to the business?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Benjamin Swinburne", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "13eea192-60b4-45b2-96cb-c744520e2f74", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: So, two quick things, and then I'm going to pass it over to Jessica. On Spectrum One, we didn't launch that until October, so it had no impact on our Q3 results. And on your question regarding high-split, we're going to go into lots of detail in December, so I'm going to try to be quiet today around all that. There's nothing shocking. I think Tom and others may elaborate on the benefits of high-split, but we'll give a more detailed plan in December. The questions on the mobile, I'm going to hand that over to Jessica around the financials on mobile and she can go through that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "4e4c7cfd-fb74-4356-8917-a1edf4d33980", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Yeah, so, Ben, mobile EBITDA losses remained due to a few things. The first one I'm sure you saw, this is our best quarter yet for mobile growth and we continue to have additional sort of customer acquisition costs, because of that, that weigh on mobile EBITDA. Also, we did see both in mobile and in the cable side increases in bad debt in the year-over-year. And so there is some of that that's impacting mobile EBITDA. And we did implement a new system early on in the year, I think Tom has talked about it. And we're still sort of working through the last of the costs related to having implemented that system, and so there's a little weight there that I think will come down as we settle in a bit more. But the key here is that you should know that gross margin in the mobile product continues to be very good. And as Chris mentioned, Spectrum One, while it offers a promotional price on mobile, we're both selling additional lines in with that promotional offer, and at our rack rate which that rolls to in 12 months. We make very solid margins off of the mobile business. And because of that, we'll remain profitable in that business absent the growth costs, even with the promotional pricing to drive overall customer relationship.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "74399622-1aa5-4324-abda-03e986702057", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thanks, everyone.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Benjamin Swinburne", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "87f92542-26ce-4bb3-8800-796a79c7d472", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: [Speech Overlap] -- yeah, at a high-level, Ben, on spectrum splits. What they essentially do is give you the opportunity to increase downstream speeds and upstream speeds significantly, and to offer products symmetrically at pretty low capital costs. When we did DOCSIS 3.1, you remember we spent about $9 on past, not counting CPE, and which was $450 million approximately to get the plant ready. This is going to cost a little more than that, but it's still a relatively low-cost capital investment that gives you a significant increase in capacity. And that leaves you in a pathway where you can continue to invest with additional technologies, including DOCSIS 4.0 to even further enhance the capability of the network at a pretty capital-efficient way that gives you massive capacity and moves us to the 10G world we've been talking about over time. And as a general concept, it takes away additional operating costs as well -- and additional capital costs when you make these investments, because the augmentation in the network that you have to do for growth -- I talked in my prepared remarks about how much capacity people are using, and that capacity use continues to go up. So this -- and we have a normal capital budget associated with that growth in capacity. And when you do these spectrum split upgrades, you get that capacity included with that investment. So, you don't have to make the augmentation investment. So it's a very efficient way of ubiquitously deploying lots of capability across your entire footprint. And I think that cable industry in general will have that capacity across its entire footprint very relatively quickly.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "25c5f6f2-f61b-4e4d-b173-e2c98c6962de", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: And I think given what we've seen in the field implementations that have happened so far, we're confident in the capital efficiency of the implementation, as well as our ability to do it at speed have both grown versus even I would say where we were last quarter or the quarter before. And so very good progress in what we've seen both in the field and from the supplier community as to how that upgrade will be able to be executed.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "e2649ba4-cd6d-4970-a129-0aa64ed127f3", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thank you so much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Benjamin Swinburne", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "1f3dbd54-bb62-40e2-8c45-4e529d58295c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Thanks, Ben. Katie, we'll take our next question, please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stefan Anninger", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "005fedf3-7f67-444b-86ce-2944b35047e1", "speaker_title": "Head of Investor Relations at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Hi. Thank you. First, congratulations to you, Tom, and also to you, Chris, on the transition. Two questions if I could. First, Tom, just a personal question for you. Can you elaborate a little bit on the timing of your decision? What made you decide now was the right time? And then second, with respect to broadband, what are you seeing in terms of broadband costs? You're obviously doing a lot at the edges of your network that would I think give you good insight into labor costs and the implications of cost of capital. What are you seeing both for you and would you suspect for fiber overbuilders that are competitors? And does it have any implications for how you think about the RDOF build? Are there any of those markets that, as costs have risen, are now less attractive and potentially less interesting to continue to pursue?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Craig Moffett", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "3951b81b-1453-44a5-8593-078f7b068fa5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at MoffettNathanson"}

section.text: There's a lot in those -- in that question. First, with regard to my timing, actually two years ago put in my contract that on August 15th of this year, I would have an option in my employment agreement to begin the process of transitioning to Executive Chairman and giving up the CEO role. I chose that date two years ago, because it was the 50th anniversary of my beginning in cable as a technician, working my way through college in 1972. So, it had a personal meaning to me, and I thought it was a milestone a couple of years ago that I might want to exercise. And then the other thought I had was at the end of this Executive Chairmanship, I'd be 70 years old that I thought, well, maybe I should think about not working after that age. And -- but on the other hand, I was -- I love this business and I love what the future is for this business. And there is tremendous opportunity. And I want to see it through, but it's going to -- it's just such a good business, and it's going to go on so long that it's time to pass the baton. So that's how I came to the decision.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "5d3705aa-08a7-4e2c-b746-b584439103a9", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: I mean, to your sort of broadband cost questions, yeah, there are cost issues, and we've had to deal with those costs in there in our numbers. In this quarter, you can see that there is some inflationary pressure out there. And there have been labor force dislocations as a result of COVID and the economic policies that the country employed to deal with it. And they're significant, but we've -- our strategy from a pricing and packaging perspective is to be the value provider and to make these products work together at lower prices and create good value for consumers and to use our ability to drive market share as the primary driver of our revenue. But that said, we have been passing through video price increases, and we passed through recently a broadband price increase. And it was a result of the inflationary pressures that we've seen. At the same time, it doesn't negate the way our primary revenue opportunity is developing, which is to create more customers faster, and to create those customers with more products associated with each connection, so that our ARPU and revenue go up together. And that's the primary driver of our revenue strategy.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "5d3705aa-08a7-4e2c-b746-b584439103a9", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Our cost strategy [Technical Issues] is real, and we are working in RDOF to develop -- we have had higher costs than we anticipated, but we've also had more success than we anticipated in terms of both penetration and the number of passings that we can develop off of the RDOF projects that we've built. So net-net, our cost is what we thought it would be on a per passing basis. But it does create pressure and difficulty for people to attract labor and to get things done. And so we're having issues ourselves with supply chain and the development of a workforce. And how we do the work, in what order we do the work is being impacted by the labor market and the supply market. So, I do think it -- the cost of money and the cost of labor and the cost of everything will affect our competitors' ability to build as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "5d3705aa-08a7-4e2c-b746-b584439103a9", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Yeah, the advantage that we have there against many of them is scale. So certainly, when it comes to being able to acquire and then to move supply around the areas where we're ready and most able to build, I think that we have -- we continue to have a very good ability to do that. And really on the cost of capital side, the advantage that we have is a large amount of free cash flow that we're able to deploy really with a relatively small portion of to execute on these builds. So we're not as beholden to borrowing on a regular basis to fund our builds as some others in the market are. So I think we continue to be well positioned. The rural builds are actually performing at least as well or actually better than what we expected. And from a financial perspective, I'm still confident in where we are on the returns that we had said that we would have against those builds.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "4f76f490-5c82-42fd-9210-c6641ba0b7f1", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thank you. And again, congratulations to you and to Chris, Tom, for the transition.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Craig Moffett", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "7def043a-1a47-40ca-bd5b-78f09cdbd770", "speaker_title": "Analyst at MoffettNathanson"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "b9a2bb85-0c9c-4d95-b55a-18ae51b0c125", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thanks, Craig. Katie, we'll take our next question, please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stefan Anninger", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "d4ee2e74-b555-4598-a70c-7989b3e664e0", "speaker_title": "Head of Investor Relations at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Hi, guys. Thank you. A couple of follow-ups, if I can. Chris, looking forward to your event in December. I know you addressed somewhat a couple of things a minute ago, but I noticed you didn't mention updates on core network capital intensity or leverage targets as part of this transition, which are things that we hear people asking about in the market. Any changes to consider here that you can give us a little preview on. And then second, I know it's early, but, Jessica, can you follow up on that, those rural initiatives and the contribution there to broadband subs? How should we think about capital spending for RDOF and other rural initiatives next year? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Philip Cusick", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "37df2291-2909-412b-bb04-5bd540a853f6", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JP Morgan"}

section.text: So I'll take the first one. I think Jessica mentioned in her prepared remarks our view on core capital intensity, in terms of outlook, and she wouldn't have said that if we didn't collectively believe that was the case now and going forward. So she mentioned excluding rural and that there may be some lumpiness as it relates to timing of exactly how you get high-split, supply chain, and inventory and all that, but the core capital intensity is -- it continues to decline. The leverage target, I heard that rumor out in the marketplace that I find it a little bit funny, because I've been at 4.5x since Switzerland, since Germany, since Charter, 4.5x had a levered equity strategy for a really long time, probably over 20 years. And I helped put that together here at Charter, and we have good growth. And the interest rates aren't all that different, in fact they're probably less for us as Charter today than when I got here at Charter. So our views on how to create value through the operating strategy and how to pair that with the balance sheet and M&A strategy and a levered equity strategy, that hasn't changed. And I mentioned the same thing in the prepared remarks. That's why we're on the topic. I know that one of the other topics out there, and I think Doug was going there, do I believe that we need to do a fiber overbuild for our entire network. No, I don't. I don't think it makes a lot of sense to have -- operate two networks, which is what a lot of the overbuilders have had to do when they got into it. We have a really good path forward. It doesn't mean that we don't do fiber. We do fiber on the increment. There may be portions in the network longer term that we decide it's economical to do that, but for the most part, and in fact in its entirety, the path that Tom laid out is the path that we're [Technical Issues] and we're not -- I don't see any reason why somebody would want to go do a full fiber overbuild of a perfectly otherwise good network that can be upgraded at dramatically lower costs and have the same capabilities.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "77413b51-89a4-4a1d-a923-f940b2065996", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: On the rural side, I guess on your first question, the contribution to broadband subs, certainly we are seeing broadband subs coming in off of the rural build that we're executing already. I think I have said that we will start providing some more detailed information about the rural builds. And we weren't quite ready to do that this quarter, but I would expect coming into year-end that we'll provide some better information. It's not the entire growth in broadband. So the growth that you see, the 75,000 additions, reflects growth off of our legacy footprint as well, as some -- as smaller amounts of incremental growth off of the broadband subs. But we are doing very well in those markets that we build out.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "848497af-c46d-4e60-963e-de0851f83f95", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: As far as thinking about how you should think about rural for next year, I don't want to front-run giving guidance on that piece just yet. I would tell you that I think what we did in this year to try to accelerate walkout and design, it's certainly in an effort to be able to build the rural builds at a good pace which I think is both consistent with what strategically we'd like to do. Because having the passings and service sooner than later is good for the business. And from a regulatory perspective, we're certainly doing everything that we can to meet expectations on that side as well and placing the builds in service. But I don't, on that basis, sort of have a number to give you for next year. So, I would just tell you that I would expect our pace to continue to be strong, because we're trying to build what we need to build as quickly as we're able to do so.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "848497af-c46d-4e60-963e-de0851f83f95", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thank you. And congratulations again, Tom and Chris, that's well-deserved.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Philip Cusick", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "281d77d0-c3d2-433e-bfe8-1af40abd6086", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JP Morgan"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "77fbdedf-f8d7-4fb6-9fce-f27ea158ee14", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thanks, Phil.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "02fc9d8c-bfde-4d7f-b5ba-e9adef198ea5", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thanks, Phil. Katie, we'll take our next question, please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stefan Anninger", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "a2ba489f-049d-460e-ae1f-a2b245a6b932", "speaker_title": "Head of Investor Relations at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thanks. Tom, to add my congratulations to the rest, it's been an incredible run. I only wish the stock was where it was a year ago, as you are heading out the door, maybe it will be by December, holding thumbs, and congratulations to you as well, Chris. I'm wondering if you can give us -- so you mentioned that you haven't changed prices on many of your packages and your plans, and you don't really see the Spectrum One offers a price cut. I'm wondering if you can comment on the pricing environment more broadly around you from your competitors. And how you think the introduction of fixed wireless broadband into the market may be impacting industry pricing more broadly?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jonathan Chaplin", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "301e2a1d-a17e-4901-94c5-e02cc863060d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at New Street Research"}

section.text: And then the -- Tom, you sort of reiterated what Charter strategy has been clearly for years and years, which is to drive growth with volumes, and to be very measured on price. And it's been clear how that's been sort of a hallmark of creating long-term value for Charter for a long time. Help us think about though the pace at which EBITDA would grow in an environment where volumes are just going to be potentially lower for a while, if you -- and you're continuing to take a measured approach to pricing. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jonathan Chaplin", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "301e2a1d-a17e-4901-94c5-e02cc863060d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at New Street Research"}

section.text: I'll jump in the first. You said we haven't changed. Sorry, I just want to correct what you said. I said we haven't lowered our pricing. Tom mentioned that we have passed through some of the inflationary cost increases, and that includes broadband. Should be indicative in terms of how we're thinking about that. And then on the fixed wireless, I'm just throwing in a few pieces here and let others cover the rest. The fixed wireless access, the pricing really is designed for a full suite bundle of multiple mobile lines and in some cases high-priced mobile lines combined with [Technical Issues] access. So I think the right comparison is if you take a look at our existing pricing in September for broadband and mobile lines, because that's a comparable comparison we're now with Spectrum One, and compare that to the combined fixed wireless access offers, I think that's the best way to take a look at it. When you do that, you'll see that we're dramatically -- not only lower in terms of price and higher in terms of value, but the quality of the product is not really comparable. I think that's the right way to think about those.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "749eae20-3c5c-465f-bad1-3ac3cf2c9931", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Yeah, I guess, I would just add that opportunity for our ability to continue to grow against the market share is significant. I said in my prepared remarks that we're 28% penetrated in terms of dollar takeout of consumer spend for mobile and for broadband combined. And so we have this big physical infrastructure, where every customer we connect to it requires no real significant in capital. And the other opportunity for us to drive growth using that network with superior products at attractive prices is huge, and the dollar value of what's in front of us is huge. And so that's the big opportunity in our structure. And it really hasn't changed. The fact that we have mobility associated with our broadband products now in a combined product really means that you have very-high priced mobile products with very small usage bandwidth basis. And we can add those into our product mix very attractively for consumers. And when we look at what consumers are spending, we can save those consumers a lot of money. So that's the basic concept and it hasn't changed. And what has changed, the technologies we're using and the product sets and how they're combined, but the basic notion of the huge marketplace with a lot of spend in it, and we're not getting much of it, and we'd like to get more, and we will.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "b344b27e-62eb-4cd3-abd7-45f56cf3d335", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: And I guess in terms of how that then translates into EBITDA trajectory, Jonathan, I don't think it will come as a surprise to anyone that based on this lower broadband customer growth that we've had over the last year really coming out of, the really accelerated growth in those customers and the pull forward during COVID will mean that we had kind of higher revenue growth followed by what's likely to be somewhat lower revenue growth versus that COVID time period. But I think based on what Tom talked about that then as we sort of execute on the converged connectivity plan and as we see some return to normalcy in the market, we certainly expect that in the medium to longer term that, that will pick back up, and so that you'll have that increasing revenue growth again. Similar on the expense side, we certainly have seen some impact and I think we called out some of the impact of inflation in the financials in Q3. But we think that, that sort of -- once again sort of is a temporary crunch on growth that is consistent with what people have -- what we think that people expect. But that will be followed by a return to more normal levels. And so ultimately in the medium and long term, I think that the trajectory of EBITDA growth is back closer to pre-pandemic levels. But I acknowledge that I think that there could be a little bit of slowness in that growth in the short term.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "4ff3b8df-316d-4c16-a4d3-1bae27c2c711", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: That's great. Thanks, Jessica. I appreciate that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jonathan Chaplin", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "1c045b7c-5e4f-47d8-9c42-082d96006df5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at New Street Research"}

section.text: Thanks, Jonathan. We'll take our next question, please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stefan Anninger", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "7b7c2c47-735f-4892-b896-867eb94449c7", "speaker_title": "Head of Investor Relations at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thanks. My congratulations to you both. I had just a couple of questions. One, you've talked about a broadband rate increase. I mean, we haven't seen it on -- in the market. Any details on what the magnitude of that is? And obviously, ARPU for broadband seems to be a big focus for all of us, given sort of flattish unit growth. So any sense on what that could drive broadband ARPU in '23? And then just for housekeeping, was there any ACP impact on the broadband net adds for the quarter? Thanks so much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Vijay Jayant", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "ebdf48b9-c582-46c0-9498-ccfe4c78ff3f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: So, I'll take the last one of those first. There was some impact of the EBB to ACP conversion on broadband in the quarter. It was much smaller than it was last quarter. And we expect it to be much smaller going forward. So I don't think we'll call it out at all separately. And I would -- Internet ARPU growth in the year-over-year, overall ARPU was flat but Internet ARPU was up 2.2%. If you included mobile and overall ARPU, it would have been up a $1.60 versus last year. So we think that there is sort of ARPU growth happening in the market, largely driven by sort of mix issues and by our ability to penetrate the market further on the mobile side, driving additional, I'll say, real growth of the business beyond just what you can get from a pricing perspective. So we feel like we're doing well there. I don't think that we'll give guidance on what ARPU growth we expect going forward. But that's what we're seeing now.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "e18945ce-9e2c-409c-8599-e8474260e226", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Great. Thanks so much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Vijay Jayant", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "b67036e0-eafd-41e1-b7d7-a2d52c257924", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: All right. Thanks, Vijay. We'll take our next question, please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stefan Anninger", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "c067743c-c3e9-40ad-b328-8a675400b87d", "speaker_title": "Head of Investor Relations at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Hi. And thank you. Two questions, one mobile. Historically, Charter and Comcast have said that mobile is primarily added by existing customers, and I'm wondering if it's fair to assume that Spectrum One represents an intent to invest what you've called the high mobile contribution margin on the incremental sub in customer acquisitions and converged customers, and whether that is the solution for this broadband problem? And secondly, I just wondered if you could comment on sequential growth. It looks to me like broadband commercial and mobile adjusting for a view of the EBB losses grew less than 50 million sequentially. I'm trying to square this with your leverage, I'm sure it's not your view that, that is the future. And so any comments on sequential growth would be helpful. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Peter Supino", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "5047febe-9c44-49b3-bd37-3ab03e6d8c49", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Peter, to the first part of your question, I'd say yes. We expect to be able to pull the broadband growth through. It's a complicated sale obviously, and -- but yes.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "fc5d251b-cd73-431b-a5f3-455c2925227a", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: You mentioned the Spectrum One solution to the broadband growth issue we have right now, and I think it could be additive, but it's not the solution. The problem right now is market activity. And I know that's not the fashionable thing to say right now, but the biggest problem we face this market activity. When that comes back, I think that's the solution to broadband growth and the Spectrum One has the opportunity, as Tom said, to drive incremental Internet growth, as well as still today the biggest source of mobile growth is by far the upgrades to our existing Internet base, which should benefit that base as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "09a59f7f-5519-4ae5-9c3c-18576911f0fd", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: On sequential growth, I guess, I would point out a couple of things. One, I highlighted in the prepared remarks, which was that the growth that we saw in Q2 was impacted by pricing adjustments that we had taken for video pass-through. And the way that those overlapped year-over-year you actually had the impact of two in the second quarter versus only one in the third quarter. So that's part of what was happening there. There also, in Enterprise Commercial, there was a one-time item that was a benefit in last year that you don't have in this year that sort of pressured this growth rates in the year-over-year -- so -- in the sequential quarters. So some of what you're seeing there is sort of the impact of lumpiness, not overall growth trajectory.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "3e121a31-c1fb-474a-825d-24683896cd21", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: On the leverage point, I would say that where we're sitting right now, the free cash flow yield on equity is so high that I think that continuing to do share buybacks presents significant opportunity for the company just based on where we're sitting on that point. And the overall capital structure I think has been an advantage to the company in the long term. And so I don't see where we are, even in what might be a temporarily pressured growth environment as being a reason to move off of where we've been from a leverage standpoint or a share buyback strategy. And so consistent with what I said, we certainly expect to stay at the top of our 4 to 4.5x leverage ratio.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "3e121a31-c1fb-474a-825d-24683896cd21", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thank you. And Tom, thanks for a great decade at Charter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Peter Supino", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "643e1845-6b64-4b32-a3b8-2c2f9254ac6f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "ca0d6cf6-8485-4a45-acbd-dc97e4ca6460", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thanks, Peter. We'll take our next question, please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stefan Anninger", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "d0c8a8ad-4261-4118-a359-a08ba2f229da", "speaker_title": "Head of Investor Relations at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thanks. And I'll just echo my congrats to Tom and Chris. My first question here is a followup for Jessica. You mentioned the merits of continuing to buyback your stock at these levels. Your debts are also trading at significant discounts to par. I'm wondering if that could also be an accretive opportunity to buy back some of your debt out of the market. And then we've seen cord-cutting pick-up on a year-over-year basis at your business and at most other operators businesses. I'm curious if you could give us some insight as to what's driving it, meaning we know that there has been fewer and fewer gross connects over the last several years. I'm wondering if you're actually seeing an uplift in people cutting the cord, meaning they get rid of their pay-TV, but remain with you as a customer for broadband. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Brett Feldman", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "ff3bc18e-f933-44dd-b980-d933e1f40396", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: So on the debt repurchase question, I also have noticed that our debt is trading at a discount in the market. We do modeling consistently as to what we think the best option as between the two is, particularly given our plans to stay at the top end of our leverage range. And so I won't comment on anything in particular that we plan to do. But we do certainly notice it, and we'll continue to do our modeling, and we'll make the next decision based on what appears appropriate, given where the market sits at that moment.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "2ae70e60-b67f-434c-b13f-74d06d2554f1", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Cord-cutting, the biggest driver here is the pricing of --
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "99fdc476-20ef-4f82-b588-a2146c99872d", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Of video.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "a4365d94-a028-4a8e-a331-c87bc7de3bbe", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Of video. And the fact that we're having to pass through programming rate increases, which still to be outsized even relative to inflation means that customers have a difficulty affording it, even if it's really something that they'd like to have. So yes, it predominantly is driving downgrades of video.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "9539dbf9-916b-4fff-a710-c2bc664d3751", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: But not disconnects of broadband.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "4d9b4737-75d8-453a-92b7-4fabef7b6d90", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Not --
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "4756b2e1-962e-44e0-8ae2-91138c79b562", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Yeah, and retaining the connectivity, really. Yes.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "35c51943-cabf-4f06-b9ed-77a68ebeda95", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: And in many cases, we disconnect the video customer, downgrade a video customer and sell them a mobile package at the same time. And they actually end up saving money obviously because they have no video, or they buy a smaller video package from us in many cases. But they also end up driving ARPU up in the sense that they buy mobile, and that mobile is a good value for them, their overall household spend is savings -- is the savings.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "2a5a7559-eb70-4bcb-a56e-e675ee7a4783", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Brett Feldman", "section_number": 60, "uuid": "2a316c84-55c7-42b9-a723-41fe3663f61d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Thanks, Brett. Katie, we'll take our last question, please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stefan Anninger", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "774b7b52-27bf-4c8f-91df-2b8fa4a1fecd", "speaker_title": "Head of Investor Relations at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thanks. Two questions. First, if I could revisit the ARPU discussion, as you're looking at that relationship between broadband ARPU and volume performance in the quarter, does this signify that there's just greater price sensitivity to grow the broadband base going forward? And then secondly, if the U.S. goes into recession, how should investors think about the sensitivity in terms of Charter's KPIs and financial performance? And as you're describing that customers are trading down in video, is there a risk that, that accelerates or that customer step down their broadband tiers? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Rollins", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "af5df671-94db-4d7c-8057-bc88c02a81e9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: I'll try to answer that. I've been through a lot of recessions in my career, and I have a hard time remembering them, because our business performs so well during them. And the reason is our products are really attractive even when consumers are under stress. Obviously, there is a certain amount of stress that you can't overcome. And video I think will be challenged, but on the other hand, it's a very attractive product if you're unemployed. And it's still even the high price that it is, is a good value relative to other forms of entertainment. So. But the reality is that in a recessionary environment when people become more price-sensitive, the value proposition that we offer with our everyday pricing is superior to what they can get elsewhere, which means that we actually become more attractive when people are more conscious of the price they're paying for other products. And so I'm not that worried about a recession from our company's perspective.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "38e6185a-4ef2-4000-9a09-86e672f731b0", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: And there might be some impacts that you would see in a space like advertising or --
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "f24e5e5e-5592-4a64-8942-cd88fefdef1a", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Enterprise.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "513067a3-8be0-43f6-b59e-dacb164c2032", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Enterprise, but the performance that we could get in mobile particularly given our pricing there would be good. And even if it had video downgrades on the other side, the margins in mobile are actually better than the margins in video. So you get some advantage of more customers moving into the mobile side of the business as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "4fb80a25-f9ac-41f8-ab1e-00412098c829", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: So we're not hoping for a recession, but --
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "dd53974c-bcbc-4bb0-9376-aaf1935b918e", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: We'll be fine.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "2a9fe268-1627-4044-861f-157bd5712e50", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: On broadband, it's a staple product which insulates it during that, but unlike many, we have not been pushing speed upgrades for the purpose of just generating rate. It's really been about when a customer wants higher speed or feels the need of higher speed, that's when it's been offered and it's been offered at an attractive rate. And so the risk of a downgrade, the speed upgrades, I think is mitigated with us because we haven't artificially driven that into the base.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Christopher Winfrey", "section_number": 70, "uuid": "89e6bd08-8e70-4f7a-91ec-9d197512c886", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stefan Anninger", "section_number": 71, "uuid": "0d89ff70-4cfa-4eae-82a3-11d403452bda", "speaker_title": "Head of Investor Relations at Charter Communications"}

section.text: And on the subject of price sensitivity, are you just -- are you seeing more sensitivity in price to grow the broadband base on a net level going forward?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Rollins", "section_number": 72, "uuid": "08cfb34d-564a-4503-99c2-97a883ef5d57", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: I mean, I think we've said the issue in broadband is activity. It hasn't been that there's additional price sensitivity. It's just that there's not a lot of movement in the market overall. And so I don't think that, that scenario is significantly different than what it's been before. We've always competed all across our footprint, and we continue to do that today. And the price sensitivity of that competition is not -- it's not significantly different than it was in the past. Price has always been important, and it continues to be important, and that's why having packages that provide value to consumer helps us to grow subscribers and has helped us over time to grow subscribers at a faster pace than our competitors.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jessica Fischer", "section_number": 73, "uuid": "fc44b902-4208-4aa0-916e-7b000a865143", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: The way I would -- if there were price issues with broadband, you'd see broadband disconnects, and they are at historic lows.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas M. Rutledge", "section_number": 74, "uuid": "45a084c4-4d2f-4be7-81a0-9edac174ffd1", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Charter Communications"}

section.text: Thanks, Mike. Katie, back to you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stefan Anninger", "section_number": 75, "uuid": "f1bd0803-406b-4adc-a6b5-a7528b5ed4fd", "speaker_title": "Head of Investor Relations at Charter Communications"}

title: Q&A for CHTR (Charter Communications) on 10/28/22 8:30 AM ET
